title: Hidden Filters of the Mind: How Intermediate Beliefs Shape Our World
description: In this article, we look at the concept of intermediate beliefs — the inner rules and assumptions through which we perceive the world. They are linked to automatic thoughts and often determine our emotional state and reactions. Becoming aware of these beliefs and rethinking them helps make our thinking more flexible and supportive.

texts: Now we’re going a little deeper — from the branches down to the trunk of our imaginary tree.
They are also called “rules” because they are the inner attitudes and filters through which we look at ourselves, other people, and the world.
Here are a few examples of such beliefs:
If I always please others, they will love me.
I need to be strong, otherwise I’ll lose people’s respect and stop being important to them.
If I make a mistake, it means I’m a complete failure.
Notice that these beliefs often sound like conditions. That’s why it’s helpful to phrase them with the word “if”.
Let’s see how intermediate beliefs are connected to automatic thoughts.
An automatic thought is an instant reaction. Behind it there is usually a rule we live by — our intermediate belief.
stepper: Automatic thought: She didn’t reply to my message, so I must have done something wrong.
Intermediate belief: If I always please others, they will love me.
Automatic thought: I feel unwell, but if I go to the doctor, I’ll look weak.
Intermediate belief: I need to be strong, otherwise I’ll lose people’s respect and they’ll stop valuing me.
Automatic thought: I was late for an important meeting, now everyone will see that I’m a loser.
Intermediate belief: If I make a mistake, it means I’m a complete failure.

test.question: Which of the following phrases is an example of an intermediate belief?
answers: To be strong, you have to hide your emotions
She didn’t reply to my message

texts: Most of our beliefs are formed in childhood, while we’re still learning to understand ourselves and the world.
Many of us have heard typical phrases like:
If you don’t eat your porridge, you won’t grow.
And then an adult with the belief “Men don’t cry” can’t allow themselves to show emotion. The feelings that build up can turn into anger or lead to depression.
And the belief about food can become one of the factors behind eating disorders.
That’s why it’s important to pay attention to the beliefs we pass on to children. It’s just as important to notice the beliefs we carry within ourselves.
In therapy, we learn to recognize our intermediate beliefs and check whether they actually help us or, on the contrary, hold us back.
We’ll come back to working with these beliefs more than once. Next, we’ll go even deeper — to the very basic level where everything begins.

quote.text: Your beliefs become your thoughts. Your thoughts become your words. Your words become your actions. Your actions become your destiny.
quote.author: Mahatma Gandhi
